questions.question: A motorcycle accelerates uniformly from an initial velocity of $12\,\text{m/s}$ to a final velocity of $26\,\text{m/s}$ with a constant acceleration of $2.8\,\text{m/s}^2$. Calculate the time required for this change in velocity.
questions.explanation: Using the kinematic equation $v_f = v_i + at$, we have $t = (v_f - v_i)/a = (26 - 12)/2.8 = 14/2.8 = 5.0\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A block is given an initial velocity of $14\,\text{m/s}$ and slides $35\,\text{m}$ across a rough horizontal surface before coming to rest. Determine the acceleration of the block (assumed constant).
questions.explanation: Using $v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2a\Delta x$ with $v_f = 0$, $v_i = 14\,\text{m/s}$, and $\Delta x = 35\,\text{m}$, we get $0 = 14^2 + 2a(35) \Rightarrow a = -196/70 = -2.8\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: A camera is dropped by an astronaut on a planet where the acceleration due to gravity is $3.7\,\text{m/s}^2$. If it falls from rest for $2.5\,\text{s}$, calculate its final velocity just before impact.
questions.explanation: For an object dropped from rest, $v = gt = 3.7(2.5) = 9.25\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: An object is launched vertically upward from the ground and reaches a maximum height of $32\,\text{m}$. Calculate the total time the object spends in the air before returning to the ground. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Initial velocity $u = \sqrt{2gH} = \sqrt{2(9.8)(32)} = \sqrt{627.2} \approx 25.04\,\text{m/s}$. Time to reach maximum height $t_{\text{up}} = u/g \approx 25.04/9.8 \approx 2.56\,\text{s}$. Total time of flight $= 2t_{\text{up}} \approx 5.1\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A projectile is launched with an initial velocity of $60\,\text{m/s}$ at an angle of $25^{\circ}$ above the horizontal. Calculate the vertical component of its velocity $2.0\,\text{s}$ after launch. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Initial vertical velocity $v_{y0} = 60 \sin 25^{\circ} \approx 60(0.4226) = 25.36\,\text{m/s}$. Vertical velocity at time $t$ is $v_y = v_{y0} - gt = 25.36 - 9.8(2.0) = 25.36 - 19.6 = 5.76\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A ball is kicked horizontally from the edge of a cliff $15\,\text{m}$ high with an initial horizontal velocity of $12\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the resultant velocity when it hits the ground. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$ and neglect air resistance)
questions.explanation: Time to fall: $t = \sqrt{2h/g} = \sqrt{30/9.8} \approx 1.75\,\text{s}$. Vertical velocity upon impact: $v_y = gt \approx 9.8(1.75) = 17.15\,\text{m/s}$. Horizontal velocity remains constant at $12\,\text{m/s}$. Resultant speed: $v = \sqrt{12^2 + 17.15^2} = \sqrt{144 + 294.1} \approx 20.9\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: For a projectile launched at an angle $\theta$ that reaches a maximum height $H$, derive an expression for the initial vertical velocity component in terms of $H$ and the acceleration due to gravity $g$.
questions.explanation: At maximum height, the vertical velocity is zero. Using $v_y^2 = v_{y0}^2 - 2gH$ with $v_y = 0$, we get $0 = v_{y0}^2 - 2gH \Rightarrow v_{y0} = \sqrt{2gH}$.

questions.question: A river is $120\,\text{m}$ wide and flows with a current of $1.5\,\text{m/s}$. A motorboat travels at $4.0\,\text{m/s}$ relative to the water. If the boat is steered at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ upstream from the perpendicular to the banks, calculate the time taken to reach the opposite bank.
questions.explanation: The component of the boat's velocity perpendicular to the current is $v_{\perp} = 4.0 \cos 30^{\circ} \approx 4.0(0.8660) = 3.464\,\text{m/s}$. Time to cross the river $= \text{width} / v_{\perp} = 120 / 3.464 \approx 34.6\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: Car A moves due North at $45\,\text{km/h}$ and Car B moves due West at $60\,\text{km/h}$. Determine the magnitude of the velocity of Car B relative to Car A ($\vec{v}_{B/A}$).
questions.explanation: $\vec{v}_{B/A} = \vec{v}_B - \vec{v}_A = ( -60, -45 )$ km/h. The magnitude is $\sqrt{60^2 + 45^2} = \sqrt{3600 + 2025} = \sqrt{5625} = 75\,\text{km/h}$.

questions.question: A $50\,\text{kg}$ crate is pulled across a horizontal surface by a rope with a constant tension of $200\,\text{N}$ directed horizontally. If the crate accelerates at $1.5\,\text{m/s}^2$, calculate the magnitude of the friction force acting on the crate.
questions.explanation: The net force on the crate is $F_{\text{net}} = ma = 50(1.5) = 75\,\text{N}$. Since $F_{\text{net}} = T - f$, we have $f = T - F_{\text{net}} = 200 - 75 = 125\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $1200\,\text{kg}$ car traveling at $18\,\text{m/s}$ is brought to a complete stop by its brakes in $4.5\,\text{s}$. Calculate the magnitude of the average net force required to stop the car.
questions.explanation: Acceleration $a = (v_f - v_i)/t = (0 - 18)/4.5 = -4.0\,\text{m/s}^2$. The magnitude of the net force is $F = m|a| = 1200(4.0) = 4800\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $10\,\text{kg}$ block is at rest on a horizontal surface. A horizontal force of $35\,\text{N}$ is applied and is just sufficient to start the block moving. Calculate the coefficient of static friction between the block and the surface. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: The maximum static friction force is $f_s = \mu_s N = \mu_s mg$. At the threshold of motion, $f_s = F_{\text{applied}}$, so $35 = \mu_s(10)(9.8) = 98\mu_s$. Thus $\mu_s = 35/98 \approx 0.357$.

questions.question: A $5.0\,\text{kg}$ block slides down a ramp inclined at $20^{\circ}$ to the horizontal. If the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the ramp is $0.15$, calculate the acceleration of the block. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Component of weight parallel to incline: $mg\sin\theta = 5(9.8)(0.3420) = 16.76\,\text{N}$. Normal force: $N = mg\cos\theta = 5(9.8)(0.9397) = 46.05\,\text{N}$. Friction: $f = \mu_k N = 0.15(46.05) = 6.91\,\text{N}$. Net force $F_{\text{net}} = 16.76 - 6.91 = 9.85\,\text{N}$. Acceleration $a = F_{\text{net}}/m = 9.85/5 = 1.97\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: Calculate the magnitude of the force required to push a $25\,\text{kg}$ box up a $15^{\circ}$ frictionless incline at a constant velocity. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At constant velocity, the net force parallel to the incline is zero. Therefore, the applied force must equal the component of weight down the incline: $F = mg\sin\theta = 25(9.8)\sin15^{\circ} = 245(0.2588) \approx 63.4\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: In a pulley system, a $3.0\,\text{kg}$ mass rests on a $30^{\circ}$ frictionless incline and is connected by a light string over a pulley to a $5.0\,\text{kg}$ mass hanging freely. Determine the acceleration of the $5.0\,\text{kg}$ mass. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: For the hanging mass: $5g - T = 5a$. For the incline mass: $T - 3g\sin30^{\circ} = 3a$. Adding: $5g - 3g(0.5) = 8a \Rightarrow 49 - 14.7 = 8a \Rightarrow 34.3 = 8a \Rightarrow a \approx 4.29\,\text{m/s}^2$.

questions.question: Two masses, $8.0\,\text{kg}$ and $12.0\,\text{kg}$, are connected by a light string that passes over a frictionless pulley. If the $12.0\,\text{kg}$ mass is released from a height of $2.0\,\text{m}$ above the floor, calculate its speed just before it hits the floor. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Acceleration of the system: $a = \frac{(12-8)g}{12+8} = \frac{4(9.8)}{20} = 1.96\,\text{m/s}^2$. Using $v^2 = 2a\Delta y$ for the $12\,\text{kg}$ mass, $v = \sqrt{2(1.96)(2.0)} = \sqrt{7.84} \approx 2.8\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.25\,\text{kg}$ bird lands on a power line, causing the wire to sag at an angle of $5^{\circ}$ below the horizontal on both sides. Calculate the tension in the wire. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: The weight of the bird is $mg = 2.45\,\text{N}$. This weight is supported by the vertical components of tension in both wires: $2T\sin5^{\circ} = mg$. Thus $T = mg/(2\sin5^{\circ}) = 2.45/(2 \times 0.08716) = 2.45/0.1743 \approx 14.05\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $60\,\text{kg}$ person is being lowered by a cable from a helicopter at a constant downward acceleration of $1.2\,\text{m/s}^2$. Calculate the tension in the cable. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Applying Newton's second law: $mg - T = ma \Rightarrow T = mg - ma = m(g - a) = 60(9.8 - 1.2) = 60(8.6) = 516\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A wheel of radius $0.4\,\text{m}$ rotates such that a point on its rim has a constant tangential speed of $12\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the frequency of rotation in Hertz.
questions.explanation: Tangential speed $v = 2\pi r f$, so $f = v/(2\pi r) = 12/(2\pi \times 0.4) = 12/(0.8\pi) \approx 4.77\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: An object moves in a circle with a period of $0.8\,\text{s}$. If the radius of the circle is doubled while the speed remains constant, calculate the new period of motion.
questions.explanation: Speed $v = 2\pi r/T$. If $v$ is constant and $r$ doubles, then $T$ must double: $T' = 2T = 1.6\,\text{s}$.

questions.question: A $0.5\,\text{kg}$ ball is whirled in a vertical circle of radius $0.75\,\text{m}$. If the tension in the string at the bottom of the circle is $25\,\text{N}$, calculate the speed of the ball at that point. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At the bottom, the net inward force is $T - mg = mv^2/r$. Thus $25 - 4.9 = 0.5v^2/0.75 \Rightarrow 20.1 = 0.6667v^2 \Rightarrow v^2 = 20.1/0.6667 \approx 30.15 \Rightarrow v \approx 5.49\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: At the top of a vertical loop of radius $20\,\text{m}$, a roller coaster car has a speed of $15\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the normal force exerted by the track on a $65\,\text{kg}$ passenger at the top. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At the top, the net downward force provides centripetal acceleration: $N + mg = mv^2/r$. Thus $N = m(v^2/r - g) = 65(225/20 - 9.8) = 65(11.25 - 9.8) = 65(1.45) \approx 94.3\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $1200\,\text{kg}$ car rounds a flat curve of radius $50\,\text{m}$ at a constant speed of $15\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the minimum centripetal force required to keep the car on the road.
questions.explanation: The centripetal force required is $F_c = mv^2/r = 1200(15^2)/50 = 1200(225)/50 = 1200(4.5) = 5400\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $0.2\,\text{kg}$ mass is attached to a string of length $0.5\,\text{m}$ and rotated in a horizontal circle on a frictionless surface. If it rotates at $120\,\text{rpm}$, calculate the tension in the string.
questions.explanation: Angular velocity $\omega = 120 \times 2\pi/60 = 4\pi\,\text{rad/s}$. Centripetal force (tension) $T = m\omega^2 r = 0.2(4\pi)^2(0.5) = 0.2(16\pi^2)(0.5) = 0.2(8\pi^2) = 1.6\pi^2 \approx 15.8\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: Two planets experience a gravitational attraction of magnitude $F$. If the mass of both planets is doubled and the distance between their centers is doubled, what is the new gravitational force in terms of $F$?
questions.explanation: Newton's law: $F \propto m_1m_2/r^2$. New force $F' \propto (2m_1)(2m_2)/(2r)^2 = 4m_1m_2/(4r^2) = m_1m_2/r^2$, so $F' = F$.

questions.question: A satellite orbits the Earth at an altitude equal to the Earth's radius ($R_E$). Express the acceleration due to gravity experienced by the satellite in terms of $g$, the acceleration due to gravity at Earth's surface.
questions.explanation: Orbital radius $r = R_E + h = R_E + R_E = 2R_E$. Gravitational acceleration $g' = GM/r^2 = GM/(4R_E^2) = (1/4)(GM/R_E^2) = g/4$.

questions.question: A $15\,\text{kg}$ box is pushed $8.0\,\text{m}$ along a level floor at a constant speed. If the coefficient of kinetic friction is $0.35$, calculate the work done by the applied force. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: At constant speed, the applied force equals the friction force: $F_{app} = f_k = \mu_k mg = 0.35(15)(9.8) = 51.45\,\text{N}$. Work done $W = F_{app} d = 51.45(8.0) \approx 412\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A $0.15\,\text{kg}$ baseball is moving at $35\,\text{m/s}$ when it is caught by a catcher. If the catcher's mitt moves back $0.12\,\text{m}$ while stopping the ball, calculate the average force exerted by the mitt on the ball.
questions.explanation: Initial kinetic energy $KE_i = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5(0.15)(35^2) = 0.075(1225) = 91.875\,\text{J}$. Work done by the mitt is $W = -Fd = \Delta KE = 0 - 91.875 = -91.875\,\text{J}$. Thus $F = 91.875/0.12 \approx 766\,\text{N}$.

questions.question: A $10\,\text{kg}$ object is initially moving at $4.0\,\text{m/s}$. A net work of $120\,\text{J}$ is done on the object. Calculate its final velocity.
questions.explanation: Work-energy theorem: $W = \Delta KE = \frac{1}{2}m(v_f^2 - v_i^2)$. So $120 = 0.5(10)(v_f^2 - 16) = 5(v_f^2 - 16)$. Dividing by 5: $24 = v_f^2 - 16 \Rightarrow v_f^2 = 40 \Rightarrow v_f \approx 6.32\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.4\,\text{kg}$ toy car is released from rest at the top of a $1.5\,\text{m}$ high hill. It reaches the bottom of the hill with a speed of $4.5\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the amount of mechanical energy lost to friction during the descent. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Initial potential energy $PE_i = mgh = 0.4(9.8)(1.5) = 5.88\,\text{J}$. Final kinetic energy $KE_f = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = 0.5(0.4)(4.5^2) = 0.2(20.25) = 4.05\,\text{J}$. Energy lost $= 5.88 - 4.05 = 1.83\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A $2.0\,\text{kg}$ block is dropped from a height of $5.0\,\text{m}$ onto a vertical spring with spring constant $k = 800\,\text{N/m}$. Calculate the maximum compression of the spring. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: By conservation of energy, the initial potential energy of the block plus the energy lost during compression equals the spring potential energy. Setting the reference at the point of maximum compression $x$, the block falls a distance $h + x$. Thus $mg(h+x) = \frac{1}{2}kx^2$. This gives $400x^2 - 19.6x - 98 = 0$. Solving the quadratic: $x = [19.6 \pm \sqrt{384.16 + 156800}]/800 = [19.6 \pm \sqrt{157184.16}]/800 \approx [19.6 + 396.48]/800 \approx 416.08/800 \approx 0.52\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: A car moves against a constant resistive force of $450\,\text{N}$ at a constant speed of $25\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the power required to maintain this speed in kilowatts.
questions.explanation: At constant speed, the power required is $P = Fv = 450(25) = 11,250\,\text{W} = 11.25\,\text{kW}$.

questions.question: A $60\,\text{kg}$ student runs up a flight of stairs, gaining a vertical height of $4.5\,\text{m}$ in $3.2\,\text{s}$. Calculate the student's average power output. (Take $g = 9.8\,\text{m/s}^2$)
questions.explanation: Work done against gravity: $W = mgh = 60(9.8)(4.5) = 2646\,\text{J}$. Average power $P = W/t = 2646/3.2 \approx 827\,\text{W}$.

questions.question: A spring with spring constant $k = 400\,\text{N/m}$ is compressed $0.05\,\text{m}$ from its equilibrium position. Calculate the work required to compress it an additional $0.05\,\text{m}$.
questions.explanation: Work done on a spring is the change in potential energy: $W = \frac{1}{2}k(x_2^2 - x_1^2) = 0.5(400)(0.10^2 - 0.05^2) = 200(0.01 - 0.0025) = 200(0.0075) = 1.5\,\text{J}$.

questions.question: A wire of original length $1.5\,\text{m}$ stretches by $2.0\,\text{mm}$ when a $50\,\text{N}$ force is applied. Calculate the stiffness (spring constant) of the wire.
questions.explanation: Stiffness $k = F/\Delta L = 50/0.002 = 25000\,\text{N/m}$.

questions.question: A $5.0\,\text{kg}$ object moving north at $10\,\text{m/s}$ collides head-on with a $10.0\,\text{kg}$ object moving south at $5.0\,\text{m/s}$. If the collision is perfectly inelastic (they stick together), determine their final velocity.
questions.explanation: Take north as positive. Initial momentum $p_i = m_1v_1 + m_2v_2 = 5.0(10) + 10.0(-5) = 50 - 50 = 0$. After collision, $p_f = (m_1 + m_2)v_f = 15v_f$. Setting $p_f = p_i$, we get $15v_f = 0 \Rightarrow v_f = 0\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $2.0\,\text{kg}$ ball moving at $8.0\,\text{m/s}$ undergoes a perfectly elastic head-on collision with a $4.0\,\text{kg}$ ball at rest. Calculate the final velocity of the $4.0\,\text{kg}$ ball after the collision.
questions.explanation: For an elastic collision, the final velocity of the initially stationary target mass is $v_{2f} = \frac{2m_1}{m_1 + m_2}v_{1i} = \frac{2(2.0)}{2.0 + 4.0}(8.0) = \frac{4}{6}(8.0) \approx 5.33\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: A $0.2\,\text{kg}$ projectile initially at rest explodes into two fragments. Fragment A, of mass $0.05\,\text{kg}$, moves at $15\,\text{m/s}$ due east. Calculate the velocity of Fragment B.
questions.explanation: By conservation of momentum, the total momentum after explosion is zero (since initial momentum was zero). Taking east as positive: $0 = m_Av_A + m_Bv_B = 0.05(15) + 0.15v_B$. Solving: $0.75 + 0.15v_B = 0 \Rightarrow 0.15v_B = -0.75 \Rightarrow v_B = -5.0\,\text{m/s}$, which means $5.0\,\text{m/s}$ west.

questions.question: Four resistors with resistances $5\,\Omega$, $10\,\Omega$, $15\,\Omega$, and $20\,\Omega$ are connected in series with a $100\,\text{V}$ source. Calculate the total power dissipated by the circuit.
questions.explanation: Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 5 + 10 + 15 + 20 = 50\,\Omega$. Current $I = V/R_{\text{total}} = 100/50 = 2\,\text{A}$. Power $P = I^2R_{\text{total}} = 4(50) = 200\,\text{W}$.

questions.question: In a series circuit, the total resistance is $60\,\Omega$ and the current is $0.4\,\text{A}$. Calculate the voltage drop across a $25\,\Omega$ resistor in the circuit.
questions.explanation: In a series circuit, the current is the same through all resistors. Thus $V = IR = 0.4(25) = 10\,\text{V}$.

questions.question: Three resistors with resistances $12\,\Omega$, $18\,\Omega$, and $36\,\Omega$ are connected in parallel. Determine the equivalent resistance of the combination.

A parallel circuit has two branches. One branch has a resistance of $50\,\Omega$ and a current of $2.0\,\text{A}$. If the total current supplied to the circuit is $5.0\,\text{A}$, find the resistance of the second branch.
questions.explanation: Voltage across the first branch is $V = I_1R_1 = 2.0(50) = 100\,\text{V}$. Since branches are in parallel, the same voltage appears across the second branch. Current in the second branch is $I_2 = I_{\text{total}} - I_1 = 5.0 - 2.0 = 3.0\,\text{A}$. Therefore $R_2 = V/I_2 = 100/3.0 \approx 33.3\,\Omega$.

questions.question: A $24\,\text{V}$ battery is connected to a $6\,\Omega$ resistor that is in series with a parallel combination of two $12\,\Omega$ resistors. Find the current through the battery.
questions.explanation: For the two $12\,\Omega$ resistors in parallel, the equivalent resistance is $R_p = (12 \times 12)/(12 + 12) = 144/24 = 6\,\Omega$. Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 6 + 6 = 12\,\Omega$. Current $I = V/R_{\text{total}} = 24/12 = 2\,\text{A}$.

questions.question: Calculate the power dissipated by a $4\,\Omega$ resistor that is connected in parallel with an $8\,\Omega$ resistor. This combination is in series with a $2\,\Omega$ resistor, and the entire circuit is powered by a $12\,\text{V}$ source.
questions.explanation: Equivalent resistance of the parallel pair: $R_p = (4 \times 8)/(4 + 8) = 32/12 = 8/3 \approx 2.667\,\Omega$. Total resistance $R_{\text{total}} = 2 + 2.667 = 4.667\,\Omega$. Total current $I_{\text{total}} = 12/4.667 \approx 2.571\,\text{A}$. Voltage across the parallel pair: $V_p = I_{\text{total}}R_p \approx 2.571(2.667) = 6.857\,\text{V}$. Power in the $4\,\Omega$ resistor: $P = V_p^2/4 = (6.857^2)/4 = 47.02/4 \approx 11.8\,\text{W}$.

questions.question: A wave on a string has a frequency of $25\,\text{Hz}$ and a velocity of $150\,\text{m/s}$. Calculate the distance between a crest and the adjacent trough.
questions.explanation: Wavelength $\lambda = v/f = 150/25 = 6\,\text{m}$. The distance from a crest to the adjacent trough is half a wavelength, so $= 3\,\text{m}$.

questions.question: If the wavelength of a wave is decreased by half while the speed remains constant, what happens to the frequency?
questions.explanation: The wave equation is $v = f\lambda$. If $v$ is constant, then $f$ is inversely proportional to $\lambda$. Therefore, if $\lambda$ is halved, $f$ doubles.

questions.question: A train whistle emits a sound with a frequency of $500\,\text{Hz}$. A person standing on a platform hears a frequency of $470\,\text{Hz}$. Determine whether the train is moving toward or away from the person and calculate its speed. (Assume the speed of sound in air is $340\,\text{m/s}$)
questions.explanation: The observed frequency is lower than the source frequency, which indicates the source is moving away from the observer. Using the Doppler formula $f' = f\left(\frac{v}{v + v_s}\right)$, we have $470 = 500\left(\frac{340}{340 + v_s}\right)$. Solving: $470/500 = 340/(340 + v_s) \Rightarrow 0.94 = 340/(340 + v_s) \Rightarrow 340 + v_s = 340/0.94 \approx 361.7 \Rightarrow v_s \approx 21.7\,\text{m/s}$.

questions.question: Two speakers emit sound waves with a wavelength of $0.6\,\text{m}$ in phase. Determine the type of interference at a point located $2.4\,\text{m}$ from one speaker and $3.3\,\text{m}$ from the other.
questions.explanation: The path difference is $|3.3 - 2.4| = 0.9\,\text{m}$. Since $0.9/0.6 = 1.5$, the path difference is $1.5\lambda = \frac{3}{2}\lambda$. This is an odd multiple of half wavelengths, indicating destructive interference.

questions.question: A pipe closed at one end has a fundamental frequency of $220\,\text{Hz}$. Calculate the frequency of the next possible harmonic.
questions.explanation: For a pipe closed at one end, the harmonics are odd multiples of the fundamental frequency: $f_n = nf_1$ for $n = 1, 3, 5, \ldots$. The next possible harmonic is the third harmonic ($n = 3$), so $f_3 = 3 \times 220 = 660\,\text{Hz}$.

questions.question: Two waves of the same frequency and amplitude $A$ interfere. Calculate the resulting amplitude if the phase difference between them is $180^{\circ}$.
questions.explanation: When two waves of equal amplitude interfere with a phase difference of $180^{\circ}$, they are exactly out of phase. This results in complete destructive interference, so the resultant amplitude is $0$.
